bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 7, 1921

div1.p: Hanson sends Carter a copy of Hanson's letter to Rose reporting on yellow fever work in Peru, and asks if Carter agrees that the situation seems nearly under control.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 7, 1921
div1.opener:
Sept 7/21
Hanson
My Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have not yet been able to get at the
questions and the information which you have asked me for so
am sending you a copy of this letter to Dr. Rose thinking that
it may have some points of use to you. I shall appreciate your
criticism of any or all points raised.

It actually seems like we have the thing controlled. Even
if we should have a sporadic case or two up near the mountains I
do not see that this should be considered serious, it cant spread
with the rest of the coast as we have it now.

What do you think of the work as far as Lima? If nothing
shows up by January, dont you think that we will be reasonably
safe?
div1.closer: Your friend and admirer, Hanson Chiclayo, September 7, 1921.
